;
;;2022 年 4 月 12 日纽约布鲁克林枪击事件后第 36 街地铁站的入口。 ;

;一名男子在高峰时段向纽约市地铁车厢开枪，导致 10 人受伤并引发全市搜捕，周四被判处终身监禁。

;

;弗兰克·詹姆斯 (Frank James)，64 岁， ;今年早些时候对 4 月 12 日的恐怖主义指控认罪; 2022 年，开往曼哈顿的火车上发生大规模枪击事件。他因 10 项罪名被判处无期徒刑，因 11 项罪名被判处 10 年徒刑。

;

;检察官要求判处无期徒刑，称詹姆斯花了数年时间仔细策划枪击事件，以便“造成最大损害”。

;

;检察官要求判处他无期徒刑。 p>;

;詹姆斯的律师曾要求减刑 18 年，称他无意杀人，且患有严重的精神疾病。

;

;在宣判前，部分枪击事件发生受害者在法庭上发言，而其他人则提交了被大声宣读的信件。

;

;詹姆斯伪装成一名建筑工人，一直等到火车在车站之间行驶，不让目标有机会逃跑。然后他点燃了多枚烟雾弹，并用 9 毫米手枪向拥挤的火车车厢里惊慌失措的乘客发射了一连串子弹。

;

;这次袭击是在火车驶入布鲁克林日落公园的​​一个车站时进行的，受伤者年龄从 16 岁到 60 岁不等。

;

;当紧急救援人员照顾受害者时，詹姆斯平静地走出地铁站，然后消失了。当局搜寻了他一天多的时间。他们使用留在血迹斑斑的地铁车厢上的一辆租来的移动货车的钥匙，相对较快地确定了詹姆斯的嫌疑。他拨打警方举报电话自首后，最终在曼哈顿东村被捕。

;

;“被告的 32 声枪响没有造成任何人死亡，这一事实只能用运气来形容，而不是被告的布鲁克林检察官在给美国地区法官威廉·昆茨的一份备忘录中写道：“这是故意的选择。”

;

;这次袭击震惊了纽约人，;人们对交通系统安全的担忧加剧;，并促使当地官员在火车上增加了额外的监控摄像头和警察。

;

;枪击事件发生前，詹姆斯发布了数十条网上一些名为“末日先知”的视频，咆哮着种族、暴力、他与精神疾病的斗争，以及他声称有许多不知名的力量想要抓他。

;

;在 2019 年的一个视频中，詹姆斯提到谈到家乡一场悬而未决的冲突，他表示“在纽约与我发生的事情将会非常有趣”。检察官称，当时詹姆斯已经在策划地铁枪击事件。

;

;今年早些时候，当詹姆斯承认恐怖主义指控时，他表示他只是想造成严重的身体伤害，而不是故意造成伤害。死亡。

;

;他的律师米娅·艾斯纳-格林伯格 (Mia Eisner-Grynberg) 表示，虽然詹姆斯最初可能计划杀人，但他一时冲动改变了主意。

;

;“艾斯纳-格林伯格在一篇文章中写道：“可悲的是，我们几乎每天都知道，在这个社会里，意图杀人的大规模枪击者很容易就能实现他们的目标，詹姆斯先生更有可能缺乏这种具体意图，而不是他只是失败了。”量刑备忘录。

;

;提到被告在布朗克斯遭受虐待的童年以及他与酗酒和偏执型精神分裂症的斗争，她补充道：“詹姆斯先生并不邪恶。他病得很重。”

;

;然而，检察官表示，子弹的轨迹表明詹姆斯瞄准了骑手的“中心群体”，以达到最大的杀伤力。他们说詹姆斯停止射击他的半自动格洛克手枪是因为枪卡壳了。

;

;过去 17 个月，詹姆斯一直被关押在大都会拘留中心，不得保释。

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 02:52:01 +0800 Pregnancy leads to permanent rewiring of brain, study suggestshttps://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2023/oct/05/pregnancy-leads-to-permanent-rewiring-of-brain-study-suggests
;;2023-10-05T18:00:19Z;
;
;;女人抱着怀孕的肚子
;

;根据研究，怀孕会导致神经元的永久性重新布线这为了解激素对行为的影响提供了新的见解。

;

;这项针对小鼠的研究表明，小鼠的养育本能是由怀孕后期雌激素和黄体酮引起的大脑变化所引发的。科学家表示，人类大脑中也可能发生类似的变化，他们表示这项工作可以为人们对养育行为和产后心理健康的新理解铺平道路。

;

;Jonny Kohl 博士，他领导了这项研究。伦敦弗朗西斯·克里克研究所表示：“我们知道，女性身体在怀孕期间会发生变化，为养育后代做好准备。一个例子是产奶，它在分娩前很久就开始了。我们的研究表明，这种准备工作也在大脑中进行。”

;

;这些发现与女性大脑成像研究一致，显示大脑体积和大脑活动的变化在怀孕后持续很长时间。尽管科尔指出，“养育子女对于人类来说显然要复杂得多”。

;

;“我们有 NCT 课程、观察学习，所有这些环境影响，”他补充道。 “我们不必如此依赖这些荷尔蒙变化。”

;
;

;;相关：;;研究发现，怀孕期间吸烟会使早产风险增加三倍;

;
;

;这些研究是在老鼠身上进行的，这些老鼠的行为发生了巨大的转变，处女雌性对幼崽没有兴趣，而老鼠妈妈则把大部分时间花在照顾幼崽上。此前人们普遍认为这种行为是在出生期间或出生后不久发生的，可能是由催产素等激素引发的。然而，最新的研究将这种变化置于早期阶段，并且还表明这种变化可能是永久性的。

;

;科学家们使用连接到小鼠头部的微型设备来直接记录小鼠体内的神经元群。大脑记录显示，雌激素降低了这些神经元的基线活动，但使它们对传入信号的反应更加兴奋。黄体酮重新连接它们的输入，导致更多突触的形成，使这些神经元与大脑其他部分的连接更加紧密——而且这些变化似乎是永久性的。

;

;“我们认为这些变化，通常是被称为“婴儿大脑”的大脑，会导致优先级发生变化——处女小鼠专注于交配，因此不需要对其他雌性的幼崽做出反应，而母亲则需要表现出强有力的亲代行为以确保幼崽的生存，”科尔说。 “令人着迷的是，这种转变不会在出生时发生——大脑很早就为这一重大的生活变化做好了准备。”

;

;当小鼠经过改造，神经元对激素不敏感时，它们即使在分娩后也未能表现出任何父母行为的转变，这表明这些激素在怀孕后期有一个关键的窗口期，这些激素发挥作用。

;

;在人类中，荷尔蒙的变化并不是唯一的，甚至不一定是唯一的。对养育行为的主要影响。但了解大脑中发生的变化可以为了解父母关系和产后抑郁症和精神病等疾病的影响提供新的见解。

;

;纽约大学朗格尼分校的罗伯特·弗罗姆克教授（未参与这项研究），说：“关于养育子女以及身体和大脑中的激素信号传导，我们还有很多不了解的地方——这些结果是朝着这个方向迈出的坚实一步。养育孩子是我们和其他动物所从事的最复杂、最困难的行为之一，没有太多的“试错”空间，尤其是在产后最初几天，婴儿需要大量照顾。

; < p>;“这里记录的荷尔蒙变化似乎有助于父母的大脑立即响应婴儿的需求，这样父母的啮齿动物就像新的人类父母一样，可以做好工作，并尽快对婴儿敏感。尽可能，”Froemke 补充道。

;
;

;The final text message contained just three words: “Bear attack bad.”

;

;Sent from a satellite device to family and rescue teams, it signalled that an autumn camping trip in Banff national park had gone terribly wrong.

;

;Early on Saturday morning, a rescue team from Parks Canada arrived the location and found ;two people and their dog had been killed ;_– the first fatal encounter with a grizzly bear in the park in nearly half a century. In the days since, family members have identified the victims as Doug Inglis and Jenny Gusse, both 62. Their border collie was named Tris.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Two people and their dog killed in rare grizzly bear attack in Canada national park;

;
;

;Inglis and Gusse met as students at the University of Alberta and worked together in a lab for Agriculture Canada in the Prairie city of Lethbridge. But they shared a deep love of the outdoors, traversing the wild landscapes of Waterton and Banff national parks. Last week, the pair were on a week-long trek near the Red Deer River valley, in the north-east section of Banff, when disaster struck.

;

;Colin Inglis, Doug's uncle, told the Canadian Press the couple had texted him at 4.52pm on Friday to say that they had been delayed but were at camp.

;

;They likely ate dinner, ensured food was hung a safe distance, and retreated into their tent to read– a familiar routine.

;

;Just a few hours later, Colin Inglis got a phone call from Garmin, the company that operates the satellite device used by the couple, telling him an SOS had been activated. They read him the message.

;

;“'Bear attack bad' means bad things,” said Inglis. “Something is probably happening right then that is terrifying.”

;

;Parks Canada also received an alert and immediately dispatched its wildlife human attack response team, an armed unit trained to handle worst-case scanerios. Poor weather conditions in the mountains prevented the team from using a helicopter. Under the cover of darkness, the team moved by foot trough the valley. They arrived at the location of the distress call after midnight and found two people and their dog, were dead.

;

;As they scoured the area, the team was charged by a grizzly. The bear was shot and killed.

;

;A subsequent necropsy revealed a bear at the tail end of her life, nearly 25 years old. Her teeth were in poor condition and her fat stores were lower than normal. The couple's food cache was hung safely, a distance from their tent.

;

;While the response team is trained in wildlife attack site investigation and forensics, Parks Canada says it won't speculate on what caused the attack. “The incident happened in a remote wilderness location and there were no witnesses,” the agency said.

;

;The couple, veterans of the Canadian hinterlands, were well-prepared for their week-long trip.

;

;“But bears are unpredictable,” said Colin Inglis. “This is a rogue bear. This is something unusual that has happened.”

;

;The family believes the couple were inside their tent, likely reading, when the attack happened. Tris, their seven-year-old dog, would have been snuggled up next to them.

;

;The Parks Canada team found the tent had been crushed with their e-readers inside. But the couple were found outside the tent; neither was wearing boots.

;

;At least one canister of bear spray had been emptied and there was evidence they had tried to scare off the bear.

;

;“There was a struggle, and the struggle didn't stay in one place. But, in the end, both bodies were back together,” said Colin Inglis. “They were reconnected. That's who they were. They were together in life, always.”

;

;Nicaraguan electoral authorities have barred an Indigenous party that has in the past clashed with President Daniel Ortega, leaving the ruling Sandinistas with no opposition in upcoming local elections in two regions.

;

;The Yatama party has been disqualified from participating in all future elections, including a local vote scheduled for March, according to a Facebook post by Sammy Allen Cubero, a Yatama youth leader.

;

;Cubero did not say why authorities had canceled the party's legal status.

;

;Police had also arrested and jailed two party leaders, Yatama said in a separate statement calling the detentions baseless and demanding the release of the two.

;

;Ortega's press office did not respond to requests for comment on the Yatama allegations. Local media reported that the electoral council had accused the party of inciting foreign interference and treason.

;

;Yatama, short for Yapti Tasba Masraka Nanih Aslatakanka, has roots in ;Nicaragua's largest Indigenous community, the Miskitos;. The party had been planning to compete for votes in the regions of Costa Caribe and Costa Caribe Norte, both located along Nicaragua's Caribbean coast.

;

;In its statement, Yatama also said the government had confiscated a pair of local radio stations that had served as a platform for Yatama leaders.

;

;The two radio stations had passed into state hands because they were transmitting in the cities of Bilwi and Waspam without proper permits, according to a letter from Nicaragua's telecommunications regulator sent to the party.

;

;Many critics of Ortega's government in recent years ;have had their properties confiscated or have been expelled from the country; and stripped of their citizenship, accused of crimes including treason. The crackdown ;has also included the Catholic church;.

;

;Ortega's leftist Sandinistas first clashed with the Miskitos in 1981 during the leader's first term as president, when they were accused of plotting to break away from Nicaragua and 60 people were killed in confrontations, according to official data.

;

;Years later, Ortega reconciled with the Miskitos, but new conflicts emerged in 2018 when community leaders backed mass anti-government protests that left more than 300 dead, according to human rights organisations.
